comments:
STAT 431, or Statistical Inference, is about making decisions under uncertainty using statistical methods. The topics include estimation, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing, single and multiple linear regression, one-way and two-way analysis of variance, variable selection, logistic regression and categorical data analysis. Interpretation of the results and analysis of assumptions is an important part of the course. This course does not have business applications but has significant overlap with STAT 101 and 102.

Students generally enjoyed the course’s practical applications. One student commented, “The skills learned in the course are very practical and a good starting point for further study,” and other student said the material was “very helpful in pursuing my undergraduate research projects.” 

Students had mixed reviews for Professor Kakade. Most said he was “smart,” “accessible,” and “friendly.” Students also liked how he connected real-world examples to material covered in class. However, some felt that the lectures were “disorganized” and “a little confusing” at times. However, it was Professor Kakade’s first semester at Penn, and students noted that the course organization improved throughout the semester. 

Though students said the homework assignments were “not difficult,” several noted that they were time-consuming and “a little bit too much.” STAT 430 is a prerequisite for this course. This review is based on the 8 student comments that were submitted.
